title: Making peace with cannabis  Zachary Walsh  TEDxPenticton

json.text: Making peace with cannabis, Zachary Walsh, TEDxPenticton
I'm a clinical psychologist and I'm a researcher.
I study drugs in human behavior.
So I'm really interested in who uses drugs.
What drugs they're using?
Why did they use them?
And what are the consequences for mental health?
Like a lot of people in the past couple years.
My team and I have been turning our attention towards cannabis.
We conducted a series of studies.
Of medical and recreational cannabis users.
So 1 question that people often ask me.
When they find out that I research recreational
and therapeutic cannabis use is...
How can you tell the difference?
What's the difference between recreational and medical use?
I think that's a great question.
Because it raises some really important issues.
About just how porous the barriers can be.
Between wellbeing, health and pleasure.
I don't think there's really an easy answer.
I don't think that there's going to be 1 sort of objective criteria.
That we can use to distinguish medical from recreational use.
There are people out there.
Who have conditions that respond very well.
To cannabis based medicines.
And they might still use cannabis a lot of the time.
Because they like the way it makes them feel.
There are also people.
Who might not think of themselves as medical users.
But they get substantial symptom relief from using cannabis.
People with back pain who smoke a joint before they go to bed.
And find they can get through the night with a good sleep.
Undisturbed by pain.
Even though they're having a bit of a flare-up.
But for a lot of people it is clear cut.
They have serious and severe symptoms and illnesses.
That they treat effectively with cannabis
and cannabis based medicines.
They don't like the feeling.
It's an unwelcome side effect.
For a lot of people it's both.
They treat very legitimate symptoms using cannabis medicines.
And mayby they like some from the other aspect as well.
But whether it's recreational or therapeutic or both.
What we do know.
Is that a lot of adults in Canada choose to use cannabis.
They weight the costs and the benefits.
And they make a reasonable and rational choice to use cannabis.
It's well over half of Canadians across their lifetime.
And about 20 % of us in the past year.
So if so many Canadian adults are making this rational choice.
What's the big deal?
Why do we have this complex and conflicted fearful relationship?
With this ancient plant?
Ummm...
I think that's really the important question.
How did we get where we are today?
Where might we go from here?
That's what I want to talk about.
I  want to talk about where we are with cannabis.
You know when we think about our relationship with the cannabis plant.
We tend to have very short memories.
A lot of us will start of with some of the cultural changes in the 1960's.
Jerry Garcia
Some of us will even go back to the 1950's, in Jazz culture.
But really if we want to think about our relationship.
Between human beings and cannabis.
We have to go back a whole lot further than that.
This is a pictographic representation.
Of hemp plants being hung out to dry.
It's at about 5000 years old and comes from central Asia.
That's where our best estimates.
Of early human use of cannabis come from.
Several thousand years ago in Asia.
Whether they use was medical.
Whether it was spiritual.
Whether it was just for fun.
I don't think we really know, it's an ongoing debate.
But what we do know is that this is a very old relationship.
By some estimates cannabis was the first cultivated plant.
You could say that cannabis and human beings grew up together.
Cannabis is been described as a camp follower.
It's a plant that follows human beings wherever we go.
And wherever we disturb the Earth.
And make a place for it to take root.
Cannabis can ofcourse grow wild.
But it doesn't mind some help.
For most of our many millennia long relationship.
We've got along pretty well.
Even as recently as just a little over a 100 years ago.
Queen Victoria was using cannabis extracts for therapeutic purposes.
But like any long relationship there have been ups and downs.
Cannabis and human beings had a bit of a falling out around the 1930's.
That's when you first see the term marijuana become popular.
It was a term that was coined by cannabis prohibitionists.
To make the familiar cannabis plants seem foreign and scary.
That's why I don't favour that term.
I like to think that my great-grandchildren won't recognize it.
If they do, they'll laugh when they hear marijuana.
I'm pretty sure that they're gonna look back on our current year.
As a strange and confusing time of misunderstanding.
So since we've had this falling out...
Cannabis and people.
How have we both faired?
I mean we're both distinct species.
With our own biological imperatives.
So what has this interspecies battlement for people?
And for the cannabis plant?
It's been noted that the psychoactive resin of the cannabis plant.
The part that has most of the medical properties.
The part that people use to get high.
I have been proposed that evolved to protect and cool the seeds.
And that's certainly true.
But when we think about how much help.
The cannabis plant has got from people.
We can imagine that the resin may have evolved.
To serve other purposes as well.
The writer Michael Pollan, in a great TED talk from a couple years ago.
Encourages us to take a plant side view of things.
To try to see things from the plant's perspective.
I think that perspective can be really helpful.
When we try to estimate what the impact of this battle has been.
On the evolutionary path of the cannabis plant.
I think when we take this plant's life perspective.
Particularly here in BC.
It seems like the cannabis plant is doing pretty well.
It's not native to this region.
But it grows widely throughout the area.
I think that if I were to take the perspective of another plant species.
One that is native to BC, the Ponderosa pine.
So if I was a Ponderosa pine.
And I had an ego and self reflective consciousness.
I think I'd be a little aggravated.
When I looked at the cannabis plant.
You know there used to be stands of Ponderosa pine.
Now there are caverns and basements full of cannabis.
So it seems like cannabis is having a bit of a moment
Not only has cannabis gained a whole lot of territory.
Over the last several decades.
It's also diversified.
The number of distinct and robust strains of cannabis.
Has skyrocketed over the last couple decades.
So in the 75 years or so since people declared war on cannabis.
The cannabis plant is bigger, better and stronger than ever.
So how have people fared since we started this battle?
What it's meant for us as a species?
I think it's cost us dearly.
It certainly cost us lot in resources.
The most recent estimates from the US.
Suggest that the cost of cannabis prohibition.
Is over 40 billion dollars per year.
That's over 10 billion dollars in enforcement.
30 billion dollars in lost revenue.
We can imagine this proportionally similar here in Canada.
But the cost hasn't only been economic of course.
It's been a terrible cost in terms of human misery and suffering.
Countless families have been disrupted by crime and by incarceration.
A lot of those come from some of our most vulnerable communities.
On top of that until very recently.
We've been deprived of a very safe an effective medicine.
So if we look at this is a zero-sum game.
It seems that cannabis is coming out way ahead.
And people are really on the losing end.
And as much as I respect and admire the cannabis plant.
I'm a human psychologist, not a plant psychologist.
So my job is to support human health and well-being.
Thats why I'm compelled to imagine a different way.
That we can maybe tip the scales back in favor of humanity.
What would it look like if we called a truce with cannabis?
As we've seen tantalizingly and we're close to doing.
So my team and I just published a study.
Looking over 600 medical cannabis users from across the country.
These are people with many of the conditions that characterize.
The use of cannabis for therapeutic purposes.
People with serious conditions like cancer. aids, MS, arthritis, chronic pain.
What we found was that.
In addition to treating some of the distinct features of these disorders.
People are using cannabis for 3 primary reasons.
To help sleep, to reduce pain and alleviate anxiety.
These are things that so many of us seek treatment for.
And our medicine cabinets are full of pharmaceutical products.
That are designed to treat these very symptoms.
Our team was particularly interested in the co-occurence of anxiety and pain.
We know these things go very close together.
That anxiety and pain really make each other worse.
So we conducted a follow-up study.
That focused on people who use cannabis to treat anxiety and pain together.
What we found was that cannabis was most effective.
Amongst individuals who were anxious, in pain.
And we're trying hard to cope effectively with that pain.
Cannabis was least effective for people.
Who used avoidant and self blaming type of coping.
We also found that among the people.
For whom cannabis was most effective.
Nearly 80% reported that cannabis allowed them.
To be more active despite the pain.
Over 85% said that cannabis helped them to think less about the pain.
That makes a lot of sense.
Given what we now know about how cannabis works in the brain.
A few decades ago.
Neuroscientists discovered that we have our own system.
In our brains and throughout or bodies that is uniquely tuned.
To working with cannabis and cannabis like substances.
Called the endocannabinoid system. [ECS]
We've also found that there's a concentration of activity.
Of this cannabis system in the amygdala.
That's the part of the brain that's focused on processing.
Anxiety, fear and the emotional content to fear.
The activity of the cannabis in the amygdala.
Raises lot of really interesting possibilities.
We spend billions and billions of dollars every year.
On pharmaceutical medications designed to treat anxiety.
And our existing medications are problematic.
For a number of reasons.
So our team is also really interested in.
How cannabis might work for anxiety.
Amongst people who don't also have pain conditions.
We just wrapped up a study led by my student Kim Crosby.
Looking at anxiety cannabis use
and psychological well-being among scholars students.
We've found something that was pretty surprising.
Something that runs counter to what you might expect to see
in studies of substance use and mental health.
The frequent cannabis users in our study.
Those who used cannabis 2 or more times a week.
Were less anxious then the non-users.
They were less sensitive to the anxiety that they did have.
They worried less and they worried less about their worrying.
So maybe if we can make peace with cannabis.
It can help us to start make peace with ourselves.
At least for some people.
I think it's worth looking into.
So if we can start to see cannabis as a tool.
For assisting with our mental health, what's next?
Well the best studies have yet to be done.
Studies that side by side compare cannabis.
With other popular medicines to treat anxiety.
The reason those studies havn't been done is largely due to barriers.
That have been set up by governments over the last couple decades.
It's  part of the war on drugs.
Fortunately this is all starting to change.
Just a few weeks ago.
The United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Gave a green light to the first clinical trial of cannabis.
For the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder.
1 of the most severe and debilitating of the anxiety disorders.
So it's a very exciting time.
And if we can start to use cannabis in this way, what's next?
I think there are a lot other plant medicines that we could make peace with.
That might help us with our wellbeing.
Among the most promising is psilocybin.
Also known as magic mushrooms.
A recent study found that just a few treatments with  psilocybin.
Helped people reduce anxiety and depression.
When they're dealing with terminal illness.
There's also an ongoing study looking at the effectiveness of psilocybin.
For treating obsessive-compulsive disorder.
So this is a really exciting time for those of us.
Who are interested in the psychotherapeutic potential
of ancient plant medicines like cannabis.
Like psilocybin. Like ayahuasca.
There's new studies coming out all the time.
And the rate of discoveries accelerating rapidly.
What this might mean in a more broad sense.
Is that in the coming years and decades.
We may have access to some of the very same medicines.
That our ancesters used effectively for millennia.
It might also mean that we might be able.
To start to address some of our mental health concerns.
Using our gardens or greenhouses.
I think that in itself could be tremendously empowering.
It could also help us to reduce the tremendous environmental cost.
Of producing and disposing of tons and tons.
Of pharmaceutical products into our land and water.
And finally, I think it means.
That the drug talk we're gonna have with our kids.
Will be a lot more fact-based and straightforward.
Then the drug talk that many of us got as kids.
Thank you very much
